I don;t know a lot about them ( or swords for that matter ) Ron but 
while =
in Japan last October ( you were there as well so you may have 
seen them )=
 there were 2 nice examples of boys swords in Choshuya Ginza, 
just inside =
the main entrance on the right. I seem to remember one of 
them being rathe=
r good. They may have just been Koshirae, the grey 
matter is fading :-)

R=
ich



Ron Hartmann wrote:
>
> Hi all -
>
> Quiet weekend. Thought I'd ask =
if anyone knows of any factual articles 
> or simply some background inform=
ation on those miniature "Boys swords" 
> that we sometimes see from time t=
o time. Some of these appear pretty 
> low-end quality while on occasion, s=
ome real workmanship shows up.
>
> Personally, I've never had much interest=
 in these but recently, a very 
> nice quality one was brought to me here i=
n St. Louis by an antique 
> appraiser friend. Now I own it. What impressed=
 me was the nice quality 
> of the fittings, the baleen wrapping and a very=
 handsome, well forged 
> blade. The blade appears to be signed Bizen Osafu=
ne Morimitsu and is 
> dated Oei 5 but more likely, from what I've gathered=
, it is more 
> likely a shinshinto creation made as a Morimitsu. Hamon is =
a narrow 
> suguha with ko-nei with a boshi swept in ko-nie (hakikake). Bo =
hi and 
> an extended kissaki, male/female mekugi with "mellon" crest. Quit=
e a 
> nice "package" as we say.
>
> I've been told some of these were for =
export, but others were indeed 
> made for presentation during coming-of-ag=
e. It would seem that 
> somebody would know more detail about these swords=
 or perhaps know of 
> an authoritative article on them somewhere.
>
> Ron
=
> STL
